description.text:
Update 6/3/2017
So I am currently modifying the design of this and will post pictures and files in the next week. My goal is to convert the printer to a ball screw driven system. Since I originally chose to use 8mm rods for the rails, I have been experiencing a lot of slop in the carriages. My newly designed carriages will eliminate this. I also plan to replace the existing 360 watt power supply with a 1000 watt HP server power supply.

I wanted to build a Delta 3D printer with a large build plate capable of printing any model.

Specifications:

  • Build plate: 18" diameter x 12" height
  • E3D Volcano Hotend (possible future dual extrusion)
  • 20" Carbon arms with Traxxas ball ends
  • 8mm Chrome rods for the rails
  • 1.5" 8020 Aluminum T-Slot Extrusion Frame
  • Build plate was originally 1/4" waterjet aluminum plate with a heated pcb beneath
    UPDATE: original build plate was warped, currently using makeshift 3/8" milled aluminum
    billet for build plate
  • Solid fill printed PC-ABS corner brackets
  • Smoothieboard with Nema 17 drive steppers, geared Nema 17 for extruder

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9vBYO5uUXhc&feature=youtu.be

Printer:

Stratasys Fortus 400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.010

Infill:

100%

Solidworks

I designed this using Solidworks. I am having trouble with mating in the large assembly. The traxxas ball joints will not move in space the same way they move in the real world. I wish the magnetic ball and socket joints were able to deal with the loads that the traxxas ball joints can handle.

title: Ball Bearing with paused addition of BBs

description.text:
This is a quick ball bearing to test adding metal parts (standard BBs) while the part it printing. Final part inside diameter is 0.25" (1/4") and outside diameter is 0.875" (7/8").

Note that the print should be paused so that the BBs can be inserted at 5.8mm high.

More info at http://makefastworkshop.com/hacks/?p=20160920

Quick notes:

  1. Heating the BBs on the 3D printer's bed can help to reduce shrinkage when added.
  2. Minimize the time you pause the print to retain strong bonding between layers.
  3. Experts: If you can reduce the feedrate on your 3D printer, consider slowing it down (~10%-20% of normal speed) and adding the BBs while it's running instead of pausing the print. Be careful! The extruder is hot and can easily hurt yourself or your printer if you get something in the wrong place while it's running.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/y25tLoYQ2_s" ></iframe>

description.text:
Since I often access my electronics by lifting up the heated bed and always had to leave it hanging on the cords somewhere, I designed these to hold the print bed when tinkering.
The gap fits a 4-5mm thick bed and the hooks are attached with 2 M3 screws and nuts.

Please note that you need some kind of base that is at least 51 mm high to mount them on the inside of the printer (otherwise you won't be able to but your bed back in horizontal position). If not, you can mount them on the outside of your printer.

I mounted them below an Openbeam easily since the original Kossel corner pieces have openings to drop nuts (or lift, in this case) in the beams while the thing is fully assembled.
If you can't do it that easily, there are probably other holder designs out there which suit your printer better.

description.text:
Yikes! Why does Thingiverse hate me? (or Opera)
I won't write & upload it all again.
Check out the Video here: http://youtu.be/BNK8JXje5JY As even with my printer I was not able to print such a tiny working gear (at least without changing everything) I used a piece of string which winds arround the axis and turns the disc! (See Build instructions below) Check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17769 for the design this is based on and better pictures / color sheme. Sorry, I still have not colored it. More Info on the semi-daily-earrings: http://thingiverse.com/thing:7120

pp3dp UP+: Finest settings, 10Â° Support angle, 5 density, 10lines, or something like that. Print speaker pointing UP
-Carefully insert disk's axis, carefully bend the parts to make it fit
-use string (not too long), tie a knot/loop, put it over that axis with tweezers
-add a small drop of instant glue
-pull string through the front hole
-knot to crank, use a drop of glue
-wait untill the glue is dry!
-cut off loose threads
-wind the disk untill most of the string is wound up
-put crank into the holes
-glue the ball to the end of the crank so it will not slip out (even though the string somewhat holds it in place) -carefully turn the crank, enjoy!
Color sheme and scale see http://www.thingiverse.com/image:110359

author: ritaxiang

title: Archimedean spiral generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Archimedean spiral is the base of Spiral moving fish.

The equation of Archimedean spiral is r = a + b * theta. If you just increase theta with the same amount, the distance between each segment of the moving fish would also be increased.

In order to equally spaced each segment, I need to find out all angles between each segment. That's what the find_parent_angles module does in the .scad file.

For more precisely controlling models between each segment, I also divide all parent angles found by the find_parent_angles module into several sub angles which may be controlled by the children_per_step parameter.

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English
Want to know how I design it? Take a look at Archimedean spiral.

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

description.text: The original nut had too many issues with the first few layers. I've made it printable by messing around with the threads.

In looking around for images of Ben Skywalker's lightsaber, there doesn't seem to be any agreement on what it looked like. I guess since he only appears in a handful of books there's no iconic image of his lightsaber out there. The models I liked the best had elements from both his dad's (Luke Skywalker) and his mom's (Mara Jade) lightsabers, so I borrowed from those two designs.

I started with the lower half and the emitter of CaseStudyno8's Lukeskywalker Lightsaber. I hardly touched the pommel and midsection - just added some new holes for more buttons. (Buttons are cool - see below!) I modified the emitter a bit and added more pieces to it. Then I created the middle grip using alternating large silver and smaller black rings like I used on Mara Jade's lightsaber.

Then I stuck a bunch of buttons on it because, well, lots of buttons on a lightsaber are cool. Totally useless, but still cool.

You'll need three small buttons, inner and outer, two large grips and three small grips. Everything is in the orientation that I printed it in. The Switch Top will need supports, but that's the only piece. I also needed a raft to keep some of the smaller pieces on the build-plate.

Printer:

Homemade

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

20%

Since he only appears in books and there's never been a toy version or anything of his lightsaber, I'm just making this up.  I mixed elements of Luke's ROTJ lightsaber and Mara Jade's lightsaber.  Since Luke's saber looks a lot like ObiWan's ROTS lightsaber, this one looks a lot like ObiWan's.  ObiWan->Luke->Ben.

title: B8 Flight Stick Replica M8 threads

description.text: This is a remix of Schrodingers_cat B8 Flight Stick shift knob. I needed M8x1.25mm threads for the automatic shift knob for my Toyota 4Runner so I edited the original file. Use the original version for the trigger and knob parts.

For push buttons I used standard 12mm mounting thread momentary buttons. You may have to open the holes up a bit to make them fit. For the joystick directional pad I bought replacement joysticks for the xbox one controllers; just the switch portion of it. You can find both of those on amazon.

The trigger I am using an old spring I had in a random collection of stuff I had in the garage and the pin is a 1/8" roll pin. You may have to open the holes up a bit to fit one that size though; I did.

description.text:
Update: The condiment car and condiment caboose have been added. I have not had a chance to print these out yet and while I don't foresee any issues, if you do come across any please let me know. Thanks!

Who doesn't need a Taco Train in their life?! I know I did. I designed this to be printed without any supports to make it as simple as possible. It is also expandable if you want to add 2, 3, 4 or more train cars onto the back you can!

I printed this in ABS because it is what I had available, but I wouldn't recommend that as it isn't non-toxic. PLA would be better or even better the FDA approved PLA.

Any questions or recommendations are welcome! I have a pic of the final product coming soon!

title: Laser Cutter (World’s largest self-assembly (DIY) style CO2 laser cutter and engraver)

description.text:
This is the world’s largest self-assembly style CO2 laser cutter and engraver.
It uses high-power 40W CO2 laser tube and has the cutting area as big as 60cm*40cm.
It all began with developing a high-power 60W large laser cutter and engraver for ourselves a year and a half ago. We turned it into a smaller version of desktop laser cutter and engraver, as Smart Laser Mini.
This time we are releasing Smart Laser CO2 which has much more laser power and larger working area.

To find out more about us and CO2: http://www.smartdiys.cc/smart-laser-co2/

1.High Power for Affordable Price
By utilizing “the fullest possible use of open source” × “Buyer's self-assemble model”, we are able to offer this superb laser cutter and engraver that is equipped with the high-power 40W CO2 laser tube and large cutting area at $2,480 (w/o tax).

2.Satisfying a wide range of needs by providing sufficient machine performance
Loaded with a high-end motor driver and a high-speed micro-computer chip, it enabled us to create a laser cutter and engraver which fulfills various needs. (e.g. personal hobby use, creative activities of designers and creators, use for educational institutes, and prototyping for corporations etc..).

3.A user friendly free-software
The free all-in-one software includes functions such as creating and retrieving the processed data of products - sharing all those data and images of the products among other users. (Supported on Windows, Mac OS X, Linux, Raspberry Pi)

Step-by-step instruction manual for assembly and how to use the software.
http://www.smartdiys.cc/manual/smart-laser-co2/

• Works with: Smart Laser CO2 works with variety of materials such as wood, leather, acrylic, paper and dozens more.

  • Work Area: 600*440mm

  • Laser: CO2 Laser 40W

  • Processing method
    Vector Method

    1. The vector method can cut along the outer shapes also It can be created in SVG or DXF format.
    2. Raster Method　
      Raster method is for impressing an image while horizontally scanning just like filling.
      Raster method can be put with SVG, PNG or BMP format images.

  • Supported OS: Compatible with Windows 7, Windows 8, Windows 8.1, Windows 10, Mac OS X, Linux, Raspberry Pi.

  • Supported Browser: Supports Chrome and FireFox

  • Supported File: SVG and DXF are supported

  • Accessories: Protection glasses, USB cable, AC cable

  • Power: AC100V

  • Size: 910820380mm

  • Operating Temperature: Below 30C (86F)

  • Continuous Operating Time: Under 30 mins

  • Weight: about 42kg (93lbs)
More Details

  • Mechanical parts.
    We adopted open builds V-slot (http://openbuildspartstore.com/) for our mechanical parts, which leads to simple and easy assembly.

  • Computer software
    Computer software works on the Browser. It’s made by HTML, JavaScript, Python. Also it’s Cross-platform, and you can use it with Windows、Max OS X、Linux、Raspberry Pi.
  • Controllers
    Two A4988 drivers are installed on the Arduino Mega.
    It is called “Smart Laser CO2 Shield”

Smart Laser CO2i Shield on the Arduino Mega

  • Arduino Mega
    https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardMega2560
  • A4988 drivers
    https://www.pololu.com/product/1182
  • Smart Laser CO2 Shield designed using the KiCad.
    http://kicad-pcb.org/

  • Download Smart Laser Mini Shield’s design data file from GitHub.
    ・KiCad data files
    ・Circuit diagram (pdf)
    ・Parts list
    https://github.com/smartDIYs/SmartLaserMiniShield

  • Firmware
    The controller software is based on the GBRL (http://bengler.no/grbl) which modified the Lasersaur (http://www.lasersaur.com/). The computer and controller are connected via COM (USB), and the communication is working by G-Code.

  • Work with Raspberry Pi
    Smart Laser Mini also works with Raspberry Pi. As you can see the following blog, we mounted Raspberry Pi 2 and 7inch monitor to the Smart Laser Mini.
    ・Raspberry Pi 2 , Monitor and Desktop Laser Cutter
    http://www.smartdiys.cc/blog/raspberry-pi-7-inch-monitor/

For some reason the stock spool holder that comes with the i3 is not long enough to hold many spools, this one is 80mm long, just long enough to fit pretty much anything.

Print with supports. If you are having trouble with generating supports I have included a model with supports generated in meshmixer.

If you have any suggestions please let me know. Enjoy!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Print spool holder vertically with supports enabled. Print nut laying down with no supports. No raft necessary. Printed in pla, though any filament should work. Threading might not be super smooth at first, just work the nut up and down the threading until it smooths out.

author: jlarsenwy

description.text: fun little project to print tools could use as necklace or earring Enjoy!

ElastoStraps are reusable hook / loop fasteners printed in soft PLA. See a video demo at: http://youtu.be/4H6pfnI9fd0
More info at: http://www.nothinglabs.com Just stretch them around two things you want to hold together - and push the mesh over the hooks (don't worry if all the hooks don't catch). I developed ElastoStraps to do things like attach lights to my bicycle. Use Thingiverse Customizer to generate a strap in the size you need - or print one of the provided .STL files. ElastoStraps are surprisingly strong when printed at 100% infill with 1.25mm thickness.

ElastoStraps have been tested with soft PLA (specifically "Flex EcoPLA" available from makergeeks.com and others). Let me know what kind of results you get with other flexible filaments - and I'll post them here! Use 100% infill when printing - and any other tweaks you need to get good prints using soft PLA. Printing in soft PLA can be a bit tricky - this presentation has some tips:
http://nothinglabs.blogspot.com/2013/09/filament-roundup-3d-printing-in-all.html If you have problems with prints pealing-up - try using a glue stick on the print area (this can really help!). If you have problems with filament binding-up in your extruder - this extruder upgrade may help:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125

comments.text: Great idea! Unfortunately I don't have a working build, yet!  I've tried to print it with multiple settings on MakerBot Replicator 2X, but none of the builds gets the locking mechanic right. I end up with a raft + 1mm of the Elastostrap pattern.

A parametric cable spool, for organising loose hookup wires etc. It's designed to be scalable, easy to print, and minimise material use.

This spool could also be useful for small quantities of filament, if you can print large enough!

The two parts are simply glued together after printing - I use epoxy, but super-glue should also work, as will ABS-juice if the part is printed in ABS.

Use the customizer to make one to the appropriate size, or download the openscad script and use it directly.

The default dimensions are good for a small hookup-wire spool.

An example customizer remix is here, a slightly smaller spool for hookup wire (the small spool in the photos here).

I would recommend that the Hub Inner Diameter should be set to about 5mm larger than the diameter of the bar / rod the cable spool will be mounted on, to allow clean free rotation.

If you reduce Socket Clearance under advanced-settings (socket_clearance) to 0, depending on the nature of your printer you may get a push-fit, and glue will be optional!

comments.text:
Houston, we have a problem: with a small spool configuration, the parts won't snap together - the inner ring is a bit too small!
I customized a spool for my electronics wire. parameter are:
Flange Outer: 40
Hub Outer: 20
Hub Inner: 10
Spool Width: 15
no cutouts
comments.author: ohuf

comments.text:
OK, made a few tests and for me, the two halves only press-fit when "Socket Clearance" under Advanced Parameters is set to 0.0 !
I'm printing this on a Tevo tarantula, using PLA.
comments.author: ohuf

comments.text:
Thanks ohuf - the parameter is just the radius difference between the inner and outer, as you'd expect. Variation between materials/printers is a bit notorious for making a snap fit like this. I tend to use glue, so usually err on the looser side by default. Not surprised a well tuned printer makes a snap fit at 0.0. :)
Glad it's working out, appreciate the constructive feedback!

This is a left-side carriage (y axis) for a lot of typical printer designs. In my case, this is to replace the carriage in my Solidoodle 2.

This is designed for string (fishing line) drive system. Aside from that and the LM8UU bearings (2x), original solidoodle hardware can be used.

Axis positions, belt/string positions, stepper positions should be very close or the same as the original solidoodle design. Actually, this carriage holds the x stepper about 10mm farther left, which may interfere with some enclosures out there.

This y carriage holds the NEMA 14 x-axis stepper and the 2x smooth rods (centered 40mm apart) that make up the x-axis drive system.

The y carriage itself gets pulled around by fishing line, attached with M3 bolts just above and to the right of the y axis smooth rod.

description.text:
I recently bought a rubber band loom from the store and decided that it could easily be modeled. I modeled this after the LaRose rubber band loom but made significant changes to it. This is only half the length of the original but is expandable so you should put 2 together to get the original length or put many together to make longer creations.
The round connector was the easiest thing I could think of to make in tinkercad to link these however it may not be the best choice. If anybody has any better ideas let me know and I can change it. I do not have my printer yet so I can't print one to have pictures but if anybody prints one please post pictures of it. UPDATE: I have changed the size of the peg that is used to link these together. It is now smaller and hopefully will link together better. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/2Wc9LJG0f4f
Print two to get the length you need and connect together.

description.text:
I love S500 frame, due to its carbon-fiber reinforced arms. But I hate the flimsy battery mount. Sometimes it may pop-off on crash and it is hard to install back. Also its unreasonable lowering reduces acrobatic flying capabilities. Lower center of gravity turns into more stable flying but makes it harder to do flips. Also if I wanna have a spare battery mount to replace it in the field - its shape takes a lot of space in a bag.

So I came up with low-profile design, easily snaps on and will pop-off on crash (so the battery, while hitting the ground separately, will have positive effect on frame parts preservation).

title: Calibration Platform for IMU and AHRS

description.text:
This is a calibration device for accelerometers, gyroscopes and magnetometers capable of doing 20 unique attitudes with 45 degrees (skewed) or 90 degrees (straight) of separation resulting in 320 potential poses for a mounted device.

8 yaw poses x 8 pitch poses x 4 straight roll poses +
8 yaw poses x 2 horizontal pitch poses x 4 skewed roll poses

For a complete calibration device you will need to print:

  • A-parts
    • 1x A-1 "cross"
    • 2x A-2 "ring"
    • 1x A-3 "weight"
    • 1x A-4 "pointer"
  • B-parts
    • 1x B-1 "crossbar"
    • 1x B-2 "crossbar fix (male)"
    • 1x B-3 "crossbar fix (female)"
    • 1x B-4 "base"
  • C-parts
    • 2x C-1 "fork (half)"
    • 6x C-2 "fixing cube"
    • 1x C-3 "box"
    • 1x C-4 "bracket (universal)"

The purpose of A-parts is to show the gravitational vector in order to align the calibration device.

title: 1Pc. Flexion Extruder Adapter for the  Robo R1 and the Robo R1+

description.text:
This is a1Pc Extruder adapter for the Flexion Extruder. on a Robo R1 and the R1+. It is
held in place with friction fit and 4 locking screws. You will need to countersink the two screw holes that hold the extruder nozzle bracket to the extruder motor for this you will need 9mm or a 11/32 drill.The two screws that hold this on the extruder motor are the flat socket head screws and you will need the clearance for it to fit in the extruder adapter.
If you mark the holes for the bearing locking screws on the black bearing holders with the extruder adapter in place, it will make it easier to lock the two together. you will need to drill all the way down to the metal bearing case (BUT NOT IN THE METAL BEARING CASE ) Make a pilot hole with a 2 to 3 mm drill through the extruder adapter that is in place on the bearing housings.Then take off the extruder adaptor so you can finish the holes with a 4 to 5 mm drill in the black plastic bearing housings. Do not drill through the extruder adapter with anything larger tan a 3mm drill bit because you will enlarge the extruder adapter hole and a 4mm tap will not fit the hole on the adapter.
Items you will need to purchase or have on hand:
1 Flexion Extruder
1 Nema 17 Stepper Motor with a 34mm body you can get this on Amazon or ebay
4 4mm 07x10 button head screws
2 3mm05x12 socket head screws
2 lock washers for 12mm cap screws
2 flat washers for 12 mm cap screws
1 3mm 05x33mm long socket head screws
2 3mm 05 20mm long flat socket head screws

If you use the adapter with fan bracket you will need a 40 mm fan

Robo 3D

Notes:

This part prints the best when it prints on its side. It only needs support in the bearing pocket
that is on the belt side. the support is easily removed if you let the Robo R1 add the support and not manually add it There is very little clean up on this part. But you will have to tap the holes for the 4 bearing locks 2 on each side, they are made for a 4mm tap. you will have to add the two holes for the extruder head that bolts to the base, and the one hole on the back of the extruder motor ( this hole is countersunk into the plastic to allow the bearing housing to fit into the bearing pocket.

title: Quadcopter Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an upgrade for the G-Intrude micro quadcopter, but it may work for any quadcopter board with 3mm holes set 23mm apart.

It is intended for 7mmx20mm motors and 55mm props.

Here's my parts list:
G-Intrude Quadcopter (or derivative): https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010SNM4YS/
4x Hubson X4 H107L Motors: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00SKVZMU4/
Hubson X4 H107 Props: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00GZHI75C

The 7x20mm motors are a considerable upgrade compared to the ~6x12mm motors the G-Intrude comes with, so it goes without saying that you'll want a larger battery too. I'm using a 680mAh Lipo (compared to the ~100mAh stock battery), and flight times are upwards of 20 minutes.

Update: Added a modified version for 10mm diameter motors, as requested. I have not done any test prints on this version though, and I do not have 10mm motors to test with, so tolerances may be off. If that's the case, you can wrap the motors with a bit of tape for a tighter fit, or bore out the holes with a pencil wrapped with sand paper.

Notes:

Setting top and bottom layers to 0 allows for an infill pattern to be used; however, be careful that the mounting points have sufficient material to sit upon. A stiff filament material is highly recommended.

Chain Guide for Beta rev3 2007

A rack to keep your caulk from rolling around in the cabinet. It makes it stack and organize easily.

A single rack holds seven tubes of caulk. For one rack, print:
One (1) Caulk_holder_back_v2.2.stl
One (1) Caulk_holder_front_v2.2.stl
Four (4) Caulk_holder_brace_v2.2.stl.

In the one pictured, I simply made two of these and glued them together with acetone. After assembling, I realized I could assemble it much easier if I simply made a brace that had tabs twice as long. That would prevent the struggle of trying to align the parts and require two less brackets. I extended the tabs and uploaded that file as Caulk_holder_brace_long tabs_v2.2. I have not tested it because I don't need another holder for 14 tubes of caulk.

Simple and quick customizable wall attachable tube holder for multiple purposes. Saw some similar designs out there but this thing is suitable for a customizer, I didn't find it here, so I made it. Just open it in the customizer app, enter your desired measures and print it !! You can even choose the # of holders in a row. Easy print, no support required, just use some brim. Recommended print in ABS as some physical deformation is required and PLA tends to crack much more than ABS. This thingies are hard to find for a given diameter and may be not any cheap. With your printer you can make a bunch of them for some cents, problem solved!! I love simple and functional things like this.

HINTS & tech details:
Remember that if the inner diameter were exactly the tube diameter it could slide down. Depending on your printer/slicer you could decrease the inner diameter 1mm or so. For example: You have a 30mm diameter tube, then you enter 29mm as diameter for the holder to achieve a better grip.
The angle is also an important parameter, as it measures the tube insertion/extraction strength needed. If you find hard to insert the tube try increasing the angle a bit. One more thing about the insertion: the more thicker the holder walls the less elastic will it be, requiring more insertion force. So, you can also decrease a bit the holder thickness to reduce it. The height parameter also controls the insertion force, as it is easier to insert a tube in a 10mm height holder than in a 50mm height one.
Not all materials have the same elastic properties. Default provided values should work well in most cases, otherwise do your own proofs.
Other materials than ABS could be used, like PET, PETG, Nylon. Even Semiflex (if you increase enough the thickness/height to reduce elasticity). Anyway the ideal material for this (and for almost anything) is Nylon, it's a pity for it to be so expensive...

That's all folks!!

UPDATE (21-SEP-2016): Minor changes to enhance renderings in the customizer app. POV render pic added.

RepRap Mendel variant using two sheets at right angles for the frame. This is an early version, please see https://github.com/nophead/Mendel90 for the latest version.

See http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/12/mendel90.html This is the 8mm rod version with NEMA17 motors, T5 belts and an acrylic frame. The latest version uses an aluminium composite DiBond frame and is available as a full kit. The source files and STLs for this and other sizes are on Github here: https://github.com/nophead/Mendel90. There are also bills of materials for each sub assembly, so you can see which parts go where. Instructions for this version are in the RepRap wiki. The DiBond version has a detailed build manual here: https://github.com/nophead/Mendel90/blob/master/dibond/manual/Mendel90_Dibond.pdf The base sheet is designed to be 10mm acrylic and the rest of the frame 6mm. Print: 10 fixing-block.stl 2 z-screw_pointer.stl 4 z-coupling.stl 2 pulley.stl and one of all the other STL files. Vitamins.txt lists all the other mechanical parts.

comments.text: Some need to be M3 because they go into motors. Some need to be M4 because they go through bearings. Some need to be hex head because there is no room to get an Allen key or a screw driver in, but you wouldn't want them everywhere as they are slow to put in. You can substitute pan for cap but I find cap easier to fit when the other hand is holding the nut. And I personally don't like ugly machines like Mendel where some of the bolts are far too long. They only cost pennies, even in small quantities so it makes very little difference to the total cost.

comments.text:
• Stepper motors are rated to run at 100C so the only limitation is when the brackets melt. There is no problem with an open design like this. Even when I box my machines and run them with a chamber temperature of 45C, the motors only run 60-70C. That it fine for ABS brackets.

  • Yes a few people have pointed that out. I will redesign it.

  • Yes that could help. It needs some with an without measurements to show if it worth doing. The PCB already has a layer of copper on the top which will have similar conductivity to several layers of AL foil. The foil may increase th
    e coupling to the glass because it is soft. Removing the silk screen would achieve the same I think.

  • You can simply make the z-bars bigger diameter and rebuild the files. With say 10mm bars I don't think 30cm would be a problem. You could also fit two sets of Z-bar clamps, slide them to the top
    for big builds but bring them lower to not compromise small builds.

  • MDF is a lot cheaper and easy to work with. Acrylic looks nicer and is lighter for the same stiffness I think. I am waiting for some acrylic parts to arrive to test this version. Acrylic will also be more stable in changes of hu
    midity, but I think you can seal MDF with acrylic paint to achieve the same.

  • Yes I will do that when I have hooked it up to some standard electronics and firmware.

description.text:
Be and Stay Creative...!

We present a toy-brick based tabletop tensometer for research and education.

What’s so great about it?
Easy to make and use

  • LEGO typical instructions make building the frame very easy
  • All building instructions laid out on this website
  • Open-Source
  • All parts are common and available from large distributors
  • In total the TTT can be built for around 700 EUR – significantly cheaper than a commercial solution
  • Easy to extend
  • Simple measurement solutions
  • A full graphic UI programmed in LabView controls the whole setup and analyzes the data
  • Measurement of stress/strain and resistance/strain progression
  • Evaluation of static material properties (Young’s modulus, Tear strength, Fracture…)
  • If you don’t need it any more, tear it apart and construct something even more awesome!

Key Parameters and Accuracy

  • Stretching velocity: 50-1300um/s
  • Tensile Force: +-10N, +-50N with an accuracy of 30mN and 150mN respectively
  • Resistance: 6 measurement ranges in order of magnitude from 0-1MOhm with and accuracy of 0.1% of the selected range
  • Sledge travelling distance: 30mm with an measurement accuracy of 100um

Project Plattform:
http://www.somap.jku.at/ltt/

Publication in Advanced Science:
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/advs.201500396/abstract

===============================================================

This work was partially supported by the Austrian Science Fund (FWFP22912-N20) and by the ERC Advanced Research Grant ”Soft-Map”

comments.text: The screws aren't supposed to go through the upper metal plate (check the pictures again). The complete X carriage, rods and the X motor mount should be resting on these pieces. This way if the threaded rods wobble a bit the nozzle will not move as much while printing.

description.text:
This thing basically holds your iphone in position with the microscope eyepiece. It allows you to turn your iphone into a digital camera/view screen for a binocular type microscope. Great for group viewings or capturing microscopic images with your iphone and microscope. Great tool for classrooms. The mount was designed specifically for the Edmund Scientific binocular type microscope. It slips right over the eye pieces. 
If you don't have an iPhone, you can print just the base mount and use rubber bands to hold your phone/camera on.

1) Print the pieces. (PLA worked best for me).
2) Assemble.
3) Attach to a microscope. Note : The iphone housing was oversized slightly to allow you to align the camera on your iphone properly with the microscope eye piece. Use strips of thin velcro or some other material to create shims that will hold the iphone into place once you get it aligned. It takes a little fussing and holding your mouth just right. 4) Insert your iphone and manipulate the shims until you get a good alignment. 5) Take some pictures and/or share the experience with someone close to you. If there is enough interest, I might tweak it or create variations.

comments.text: This design is SPECIFICALLY for the Edmunds binocular scope and iPhone 1. If you want a custom adapter for your microscope or telescope and phone, try this OpenSCAD version with a slightly different design. : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231265http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...

description.text: This is a 52mm Camera Lens Cap that i made myself. It does not require any special tools to assemble or bolts. IT is assembled entirely by pressure/friction and it holds really well on my printer. When you try it on your lens be sure that the bottom of the cap is not scratching the lens. You can glue a piece of cloth on the bottom side if you want to be safe. On the lens I tested it it was working great (Nikon 18-55mm). I AM NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR DAMAGED LENSES - check your clearance and force.

Notes:

Part 1 and 2 are designed to be printed without supports, just be sure to orient them correctly, Part two might have to be rotated 180 degrees. Part 3 (the spring part) needs support.

I designed the part in Onshape - if anybody wants to modify it, feel free to do so. I only ask if you share your version to provide the link to the original thingyverse page of the project and the onshape link.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/c5aed6d510d5a2cb1b7d35ef/w/3c7fd3d0a6a965b111563a8a/e/6cf8266704fed8352b48062b

comments.text: Is there some trick to printing this?  I've tried it 3 times now using ABS and PLA and the parts just don't fit together at all :-(
comments.author: czei

comments.text: Hi, the tolerances are such that the parts should fit together, but not too tight. You should be able to press them together by hand, but you can also try to tap them with a hammer. Maybe you are overextruding? I would suggest printing something like the 20mm calibration cube and check with a caliper if it's exactly 20mm
comments.author: czei

comments.text: Printed a 20mm calibration cube.  It measures 19.98 on the Y, and 19.88 on X.   That's the best I've been able to get with this printer, and still within .12mm.

H2O ICE CUBE
Rethinking the traditional ice cube tray, we pointed out/came along with various flaws this everyday-use product has. Say goodbye to ice cube popping. No more spilling water all over your clothes, your floor, every time you walk a tray of ice to the freezer. That annoying moment after you fill the tray at the sink and walk it over to the freezer, trying not to spill the water. At last but least…taking out one ice cube at a time seems quite impossible and hard to accomplish!
tray that can minimize the mess and is easy to use. The “H2O cubes” ice cube tray is composed of a clear tube and a flexible, plastic divider with a handle, so you don’t have to drop ice in your drink with your hands. You simply fill the tube with water, you place the divider and you freeze the tray. Once ready, to take the ice out of the tube, all you need is to smash it against the side of the counter, the table or any other hard surface to get the ice loosened up a bit, and then the ice will easily fall out as you slide the tube open.

Additionally, regarding the “one-at-a-time” ice cube problem, the “H2O cubes” ice cube tray allows you to drop as many ice cubes as you want into your drink, simply by sliding the divider out.
NGSS
You just need to print out the 3 components and connect all together.

This is a knife block based on the Giger Alien Head.

Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:579768

I imported it into Tinkercad, added some slots for the knives and scaled it up slightly so that it fits my printer bed diagonally.

Printed on an Anet A8 0.3mm layer height.
Sliced with Cura 15 which provided supports in the front and back overhanging sections.

To finish it, I covered it in black nail polish, this helps hide the grooves that are created from printing.
To add detail I mixed Black, Clear, Yellow and Silver nail polish.

Total cost of to make was about £8

UPDATE:
I have also split the block in two so overhangs are prevented.
This will require joining and possibly filling of this join but will save a lot of support filament and be quicker to print.
Also, you can scale it up larger if you want and it will fit on smaller build areas.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

comments.text: I must know how you got the paint to look like that? Has a cool antique look. When you say you mixed the colors together, do you mean you did a layer of each or you mixed all of those colors together to create that color?
comments.author: TheGreatMrBill

comments.text:
Hi,
I first painted the whole model in black nail polish, I only used cheap stuff at £1 per bottle.
Then mixed some clear, silver, yellow and a touch of black together and did the detailing
The clear adds some transparency and helps give it some 3d and is quite forgiving.
I painted the teeth silver, and then mixed some clear and silver to create the highlights on the edges.
I think the important thing is to use mainly clear tinted with colour after the base coat,
The yellow mixed with black and clear ages it quite well.
Nail polish works quite well as its thick and helps fill any imperfections.

title: Oculus Rift CV1 Sensor Wall Mount

description.text:
Simple wall mount for the Oculus Rift CV1 Sensor.

Designed to be stuck on a wall with 3M Double sided tape, or screwed to the wall.
(Picture is of previous print, without the added screw hole)

Print "as is".
Holes are set for the Tube and Cable.

Reduce to about 98% scale for a tight fit.
Your printer will be different, so experiment.

Best to insert sensor into the mount, and then use the plastic clip that comes on the cable and mount to secure into the holder. See pic.

I designed this for the screw hole to go underneath, so that the Rift Sensor sits flush against the wall, however, You can flip the mount if you like so the screw is on the upperside and the sensor will still fit into the holes and will rest on the flat top of the "triangle"

No

description.text: A quick print and a must for Star Wars Rebellion fans.

How many times you found yourself in a position to dispose your soda or beer, because the can is not re-closable?

With this protective cap, you can keep it fresh longer and store in the refrigerator in order to enjoy later..
The distinctive design offers the user protection from pesky intruders, such as dust or insects, especially during summer, at the beach. The small notch on top, when aligned with the orifice, allows the penetration of the straw while keeps the drinking straw fixed, which often rises due to buoyancy. Once rotated 180 degrees, it seals the orifice and protects the content not to spill due to accidental fall.
Features additional opener which make less painful the opening process, while protecting your manicure.
Fun for kids and very useful even for professional bartenders, turns your boring can into something more personalized, so that you never confuse your drink when in public places such as cafeterias or dinning halls..

Cheers!

description.text:
https://youtu.be/0A8flxN1KL4
First Printer project completely or pla abs 3d. Size 20x20x20 cm Print Plan about 10 cm was a long time I was trying to play a printer with other 3D printer, but the lack of design knowledge each have slowed me down. I know it's not perfect and there are some mistakes, but the printer works perfectly ... I used mega ramps 1.4 4 nema 17 engines for the plane I used Stripboard with resistance below conrad purchased on the site http://www.conrad.it/ce/it/product/532878/Lamina-riscaldante-Autoadesivo-12-VDC-12-VAC-12-W-Tipo-di-protezione-IPX4-L-x-L-110-mm-x-77-mm-Thermo/?ref=home&rt=home&rb=1 Pulleys gt2 20 teeth from 8 mm rods extruder E3D will ... regular updates and firmware for the frames you will have to divide it into 2 parts so you can print ... inside I always put bars 8 mm in the 4 corners, all filled with epoxy glue .. for any questions, ask them and shall answer as soon as possible .. are also accepted ideas to improve everything. GOOD WORK https://youtu.be/HbbWxFJLEps More from 3D Printers view more

Primo progetto di stampante 3d completamente in pla o abs.
Dimensioni 20x20x20 cm
Piano stampa 10 cm circa
Era da tempo che cercavo di riprodurre una stampante con un altra 3d printer, ma la scarsa conoscenza del disegno cad mi hanno frenato.
So che non e perfetto e ci sono alcuni errori ma la stampante funziona perfettamente...
Ho usato mega ramps 1.4
4 motori nema 17
Per il piano ho usato basetta millefori con resistenza al di sotto acquistato sul sito conrad http://www.conrad.it/ce/it/product/532878/Lamina-riscaldante-Autoadesivo-12-VDC-12-VAC-12-W-Tipo-di-protezione-IPX4-L-x-L-110-mm-x-77-mm-Thermo/?ref=home&rt=home&rb=1
Pulegge gt2 20 denti
Barre da 8 mm
Estrusore e3d...
Verranno pubblicati aggiornamenti periodici e il firmware
https://youtu.be/1jPV-cLQ9VU

title: Parametric Light Fixture Lens Cover for Overhead Lights

description.text:
This is a parametric lens cover for overhead recessed lights. Simply input the measurements in mm for your light in either the customizer app or the openscad, render a new stl and print flat on any standard RepRap 3-D printer or similar.

author: jpearce

description.text: This is a model of a hover bike that I would wish to create someday.

Helmets save lives.
They are also bulky and hard to store. Helmet hangers, albeit necessary, are very hard to find on the market.

Unfortunately, a lot of riders their helmets behind. Forcing the rider to hold his helmet before he starts his engine lowers the chances of leaving it behind.

This hanger follows a process. First the jacket, then the helmet and finally the keys. The keys are stored under the helmet, so the rider must pick the helmet in order to get the keys. With the helmet already in hands hopefully more rider will take the helmet with them.

This is a customizable food scraper. Print 100% infill with polycarbonate or similar on a RepRap for cleaning dishes etc.

This component is part of an open source lab library, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group.

For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs
